Comment: A very fair point, and I think it would have been on the chopping block eventually, but once again, we're exploring a sunk cost fallacy where decades of R&D and billions of dollars will have been spent with no end goal. Might have been a lose-lose situation either way, but once again, leaving a fascist oligarch with a monopoly over U.S. space travel just feels so wrong.  And I personally don't think having a functioning moon rocket in any capacity is a bad deal, no matter how expensive, because few countries can say they have one. Saturn V was also expensive as fuck but it had clear trickle down effects in science and technology — and put American astronauts on the moon. The Trump administration is making it clear that we are surrendering our technological pursuits to other countries like China by scrapping decades' worth of public sector R&D, even if the results of that labor weren't efficient or optimal.  Commercial "could do" is all hypothetical and hasn't been proven yet. I believe we should stick with what we have until alternatives are present and functioning. Nobody knows what the eventual cost figures for a Starship launch and recovery would look like until they actually produce a complete mission. Hopefully, cheaper commercial alternatives will revolutionize trips into deep space, but we just don't have data on it because that technology doesn't currently exist.

Comment: You're telling me the guy on my TV might not be telling the whole truth? On *my* TV? Ha! I know that guy on the channel *you* watch lies, but *my* TV guy tells it like it is.  **Genuine answer:** no, most of us don't. Your typical "woke lib" might occasionally read a BBC story, and the "progressive" wing might even watch a special on Al Jazeera if there's an international issue they're particularly interested in, but mostly we just rely on tribalism for truth.    And this is ultimately what happens when you turn consumption into identity. Comment: Thanks for such a detailed answer, I used to travel to the US quite often, 7-8 times a year for work but never paid attention to the TV or what people outside of those companies actually did. Genuinely worried for you all

Comment: We in the US used to have quality reporters, they are mostly gone or have died. We are used to being told the truth and we expect that. That is not the case. We are lied to on a daily basis and are not even aware of it.  Reporters are now "Journalists". There is no reporting, only entertainment. We are fed the mush that corporations want us to feed on and we don't even know we are being lied to, or at the very least, not told the whole story.
Author: Sunnyjim333

Comment: Thank you for your concern. I'm genuinely worried for us, too! But I've survived hard things before and I'll do it again and again until I can't anymore. That's all I've got for hope right now, but you've got to hold on to *something*.  If you'd like to do something to help, the one thing I'd ask is that you make sure this shit doesn't take root in your country. It happens slowly at first and then all at once. Keep an eye out for Umberto Eco's [14 signs!](https://www.openculture.com/2024/11/umberto-ecos-list-of-the-14-common-features-of-fascism.html#google_vignette)

Comment: Australia had our election just this weekend and our conservatives lost in an unprecedented landslide.  Their leader, Dutton who we call Temu Trump, lost his own seat after 24 years along with a lot of other long standing MPs on the right.  Our left party ALP and Greens now have a combined majority in the senate too, for the first time in decades.  A big factor in their loss was Australians, even traditional conservatives, not wanting to become anything like US under Trump. We get a lot of news and we know how bad it is..
